docs.lead_paragraph: On a cloudy Saturday this summer, two teen-agers gave birth in this West Texas border town. One, a 17-year old impoverished Mexican girl, slipped across the border to have her baby boy delivered by a lay midwife here, making him an American citizen. The child, born with devastating birth defects, was sent for immediate surgery to R. E. Thomason General Hospital, the local public hospital charged with caring for the sick, regardless of their ability to pay. The surgery, plus weeks of intensive care, saved the baby's life, but it cost Thomason and taxpayers some $40,000, not a penny of which is likely to be reimbursed.

headline.main: Hospitals Serving the Poor Struggle to Retain Patients
headline.kicker: HOSPITALS OF LAST RESORT A special report.

docs.abstract: Special report, Hospitals of Last Resort, on profound change in nation's health-care system, in which private hospitals and doctors have begun to court Medicaid patients they once shunned because of government dollars such patients bring with them, leaving public hospitals with patients nobody wants, namely, uninsured, AIDS patients, drug addicts and illegal immigrants; while shift has created wealth of possibilities for Medicaid patients, including more comfortable hospitals and more respectful treatment, is has posed vexing problems for public hospitals, which must not only compete harder for Medicaid recipients who make up bulk of their paying patients, but must also fight perception that they offer second-class care; change highlights great unfinished business of American health-care revolution, of who will care for poorest of poor and uninsured in increasingly competitive hospital market; nightmare scenario, health experts say, is downward spiral in which desirable patients and doctors forsake public hospitals as sinkholes of medicine; erosion of nation's public hospitals, exacerbated by cost-cutting by cities and states, raises special concern about future of uninsured, whose numbers now top 43 million; photos; chart (L)
docs.snippet: On a cloudy Saturday this summer, two teen-agers gave birth in this West Texas border town.    One, a 17-year old impoverished Mexican girl, slipped across the border to have her baby boy delivered by a lay midwife here, making him an American...

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: North Korea's representative at the United Nations, who has been hospitalized in New York since Aug. 12 without medical insurance or financial help from his impoverished Government, has received pledges of aid from Korean-Americans, according to Korean-language newspapers. The prospective donors, who are believed to be of varying political views, apparently fear that the envoy, Kim Hyong U, could be recalled by Pyongyang and sent home without treatment. Mr. Kim, 62, is a patient at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan, where he is undergoing tests, hospital officials said today. They said they could not give more details about his health without his consent.

headline.main: Korean-Americans Assist an Ailing Envoy From the North

docs.abstract: Kim Hyonh U, North Korea's Ambassador to UN hospitalized in New York since August 12 without medical insurance or financial help from impoverished Government, has reportedly received pledges of aid from Korean-Americans (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Preliminary Charges Filed Against Photographers A French judge filed preliminary charges against the six photographers and a motorcyclist whose pursuit of Diana, Princess of Wales, might have caused the high-speed car accident in Paris that led to her death, that of her companion, Dodi al-Fayed, and their driver. A1 The exact circumstances of the car accident remained for the most part unclear. The driver, found to be drunk, was known for his seriousness. And photographers who were allegedly closely pursuing Diana managed to avoid the crash. Lawyers for the Fayed family asserted that the driver was fatally distracted by photographers on motorcycles. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: For Sally Furbish, life once seemed almost unbearable. By the time she turned 30, she had attended five colleges, nearly set her house on fire and struggled to find her way driving from one town to the next. She had worked as a waitress and a flight attendant but seldom showed up on time. A doctor finally identified the trouble as attention deficit disorder. With medication and therapy, Ms. Furbish eventually returned to college, graduated six years later and is now, at 37, a special-education teacher in Gainesville, Ga.

headline.main: Attention Disorder Is Found In Growing Number of Adults

docs.abstract: Attention Deficit Disorder, once diagnosed primarily in school-age children, is being diagnosed in record number of adults; several recent studies estimate between 6 million and 9.5 million Americans suffer from disorder, making it as common as severe clinical depression or drug abuse; after spotting it in generations of children, psychiatrists have only recently accepted that illness carries over into adulthood; at current pace, adults will receive 729,000 prescriptions in 1997 for Ritalin, mild stimulant used to treat disorder, compared with 217,000 in 1992; critics say illness is being overdiagnosed, and many question whether it really exists; of particular concern is growing use of Ritalin as recreational stimulant by college students and fast-track professionals; photos; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN recent years biodiversity, the number of different species in an ecosystem, has sometimes been treated like the Holy Grail. Researchers have shown that biodiversity leads to greater productivity and better retention of nutrients, both often interpreted as signs of ecosystem health. But while this result has been hailed by conservationists, scientists still have not been able to say just why it should be so.

headline.main: New Studies Reassess Importance of Biodiversity

docs.abstract: Modern tenet that biodiversity is essential in nature is called into question by three independent studies, published in Nature, which suggest that key to how ecosystems function may not be number of species, but which ones are included; researchers studying Minnesota prairies, California grasslands and Swedish subarctic islands find that presence of certain key species, such as early or late season growers, can have much greater importance than others that can appear or disappear to little effect (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The year is 2025. The nation has twice as many old people as it has children; its economy is groaning under the weight of heavy taxes; its population is shrinking, and the Government's reserve of social security funds has run dry.

headline.kicker: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Face of The Future In Japan

docs.abstract: Japan, once fastest-growing economy on the globe is now world's most rapidly aging industrial society; with one person in six already older than 65, challenge of how Japan will support its aging society grows more bedeviling with each passing year; most older Japanese receive Government-sponsored health care and a pension, but the system is in danger of becoming so expensive that it will send taxes soaring and weaken the economy; graph; photos (L)
docs.snippet: The year is 2025. The nation has twice as many old people as it has children; its economy is groaning under the weight of heavy taxes; its population is shrinking, and the Government's reserve of social security funds has run dry.
